explanation:
Why each symbol is required for MISRA memcmp rule analysis:

- OS_CHECK_STRING
  - This macro/function is invoked directly on both input strings (devname, mountpoint). Its implementation must be inspected because it might use memcmp (or other standard string routines) to validate or compare null-terminated strings.

- OS_filesys_internal_record_t
  - The sizeof(filesys->device_name) and sizeof(filesys->virtual_mountpt) expressions (used by OS_CHECK_STRING and by strncpy later) come from this structure. The structure definition reveals whether these fields are char arrays (null-terminated strings) and their sizes — necessary to decide whether any memcmp usage would be comparing null-terminated strings.

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET
  - This macro retrieves the filesys record from the object table. The macro or related object-table code might perform name comparisons (e.g., when resolving tokens) that could use memcmp; inspect its expansion/implementation.

- OS_ObjectIdGetByName and OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch
  - OS_mount calls OS_ObjectIdGetByName which in turn calls OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch. These routines perform name-based lookups; their implementations must be checked to see if they compare supplied name strings using memcmp (which would violate the MISRA rule if used to compare null-terminated strings).

- OS_ObjectIdRelease
  - Called unconditionally to release the token. Its implementation or code it calls could perform checks or comparisons involving names/tokens; include to rule out indirect memcmp usage.

- OS_FileSysMountVolume_Impl
  - This important callee performs the platform-specific mount operation and may compare mountpoint or device name strings internally. It should be inspected for any memcmp usage comparing null-terminated strings.

- memcmp (standard library symbol)
  - The rule targets use of memcmp. The entire code paths above must be scanned for direct calls to memcmp to determine a violation.

- strcmp, strncmp, strnlen, strlen (standard string routines)
  - Include these to check for alternative string-comparison/length-check patterns. If code uses strncmp/memcmp interchangeably or misuses these APIs, it may still relate to the MISRA concern. strnlen/strlen are relevant to determine whether strings are treated as null-terminated or length-limited.

- strncpy
  - Used in OS_mount itself to copy the virtual mount point. Inspecting surrounding use of strncpy and the size fields from the struct helps determine whether strings are guaranteed to be null-terminated and therefore whether subsequent or prior comparisons (in this function or callees) might improperly use memcmp on null-terminated strings.

In short: examine OS_CHECK_STRING and the implementations of the name-lookup and mount helper functions (and the filesys record/macro definitions) plus all standard string routines so you can locate any memcmp usage and determine whether it is being applied to null-terminated strings (which would violate the MISRA rule).
